subject: Psychology
title: The Adolescent Brain
description: A fast breakdown of The Adolescent Brain for builders.

hook.text: A teenager makes a reckless decision with friends watching. Alone, she'd never do it. Her brain explains why.

buildup.text: The adolescent brain is under construction. The limbic system (emotion) matures before the prefrontal cortex (judgment).

discovery.text: This gap explains teenage risk-taking: strong emotional impulses with still-developing braking systems.

twist.text: Peers amplify the imbalance. The reward system fires harder when friends are present, making risky choices feel better.

climax.text: Adolescent risk-taking isn't defiance or stupidity. It's biology â€” a brain built to explore, push limits, and separate.

punchline.text: The teenage brain isn't broken. It's just not finished yet.

quiz.question: Why do teenagers take more risks?
options: The emotional brain matures before the judgment center
They have fully developed prefrontal cortices
Their brains are identical to adults
